title: Modiâ€™s dog whistle on Muslims not the only time EC has ignored contentious statements by BJP leaders
content:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi came under intense criticism on Sunday for claiming at an election rally in Rajasthan that the Congress would distribute citizensâ€™ property â€œto those who have more children and those who are infiltratorsâ€ if it came to power.Many on social media appealed to the Election Commission to take action against Modi, contending that his remarks violated the Model Code of Conduct. Until this story was published on Monday evening, the commission had not reacted to the statements.The developments have once again brought into focus on allegations that the Election Commission is biased in favour of the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party.This is not the first time the Election Commission has faced allegations that it has failed to punish BJP leaders for violating the Model Code of Conduct.What does the Model Code of Conduct say?The Model Code of Conduct is a set of guidelines issued by the Election Commission for political parties and candidates to follow during poll campaigns. It sets guardrails for speeches, meetings, processions, election manifestos, polling and several other areas.The general conduct section bars â€œany activity which may aggravate existing differences or create mutual hatred or cause tensionâ€ between groups. It also mandates that parties and candidates must â€œrefrain from criticism of all aspects of private lifeâ€ of their opponents.It also prohibits appeals â€œto caste or communal feelings for securing votesâ€. The guidelines note: â€œmosques, churches, temples or other places of worship shall not be used as [a] forum for election propagandaâ€.
		
	Photo: Election Commission websiteBJPâ€™s campaign on religious groundsIn Modiâ€™s speech in Rajasthanâ€™s Banswara city, he claimed that the Congress-led government under  Manmohan Singh had said that Muslims have the first right over the nationâ€™s resources.â€œThis means that they will collect peopleâ€™s wealth and distribute it to whom?â€ Modi asked. â€œTo those who have more children. To the infiltrators. After the meeting, Modi tweeted photos of himself saying that he watched a video of the â€œsurya tilakâ€ ritual. Several other BJP leaders have also used the Hindu deity Ram as a symbol to ask for votes. The partyâ€™s candidate from the Meerut constituency, Arun Govil, received a notice from the district magistrateâ€™s office after he displayed a photo of the deity at an election rally.However, the action did not deter BJP leaders from repeating such gestures. In election roadshow shortly after, Union Home Minister Amit Shah also held up a photo of Ram.Amit Shah uses pic of Ram during  Election campaign despite Model code of Conduct.Kya kar lega tu @ECISVEEP ?? pic.twitter.com/6aGBNqFDn3â€” Nehr_who? At a public meeting held in Meerut on April 18 as part of Govilâ€™s campaign, Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Adityanath urged voters to â€œbring to power the person who brought Ramâ€. Adityanath then went on to say: â€œHere, Arun Govil, who played the role of Shri Ram is himself your candidate.â€Adityanath was referring to Govil's portrayal of the deity in Ramayana, a popular TV serial in the 1990s.à¤œà¥‹ à¤°à¤¾à¤® à¤•à¥‹ à¤²à¤¾à¤ à¤¹à¥ˆà¤‚, à¤¹à¤® à¤‰à¤¨à¤•à¥‹ à¤²à¤¾à¤à¤à¤—à¥‡ ğŸ™@myogiadityanath #Meerut #BJP #YogiAdityanath #ArunGovil pic.twitter.com/xMe0LWJ8hPâ€” Arun Govil (@arungovil12) April 18, 2024


The Hindi slogan â€œJo Ram ko laayen hain, hum unko layengeâ€ has also been used as hashtags and campaign slogans by BJP leaders. We will bring in those who have brought Ram. It is a reference to the BJPâ€™s support for the Ram temple inaugurated by Modi in Ayodhya on January 22 on the site of the Babri mosque. The mosque had been illegally demolished by Hindutva supporters in 1992.Election Commission bans religious appeals, yet BJP calls for 'one vote for Ram Mandir'. The Election Commission has drawn criticism from Opposition leaders and social media users for failing to take decisive action against BJP leaders. In cases where it has responded, the poll bodyâ€™s  actions have raised questions.For example, after a video of Madhavi Latha, the BJP candidate for the Hyderabad seat, miming at shooting an arrow at a mosque created a controversy, an official of the Election Commission said that he had not seen the clip even though it had been widely shared on social media. The Hyderabad Police have filed a first information report against Latha.But in the absence of action from the Election Commission, BJP leaders have continued to appeal for votes on religious grounds.Brazen. The Election Commission must act at least for the sake of the institution. The ruling party is openly indulging in seeking votes on the grounds of religion. @rajivkumarec @ECISVEEP @SpokespersonECI https://t.co/fzb4gWp4K6â€” Saurav Das (@SauravDassss) April 22, 2024


What can the Election Commission do?Delhi-based Senior Advocate Sanjoy Ghose told Scroll that Modiâ€™s comments at the Banswara rally on Sunday are a clear violation of the Model Code of Conduct. â€œThe Election Commission can suspend Modi, or whoever makes such a speech, from campaigning for a certain duration and it has done so many times in the past,â€ Ghose said.He also said that the speech violated Section 153A of the Indian Penal Code (promoting enmity between different groups) and Section 123 of the Representation of the People Act.The law deems it to be a corrupt practice if an election candidate makes an appeal to voters to cast their ballots â€œbased on his/her religion, race, caste, community, or languageâ€.â€œThe Election Commission should take steps to file cases against Modi, or whoever else, is violating these laws,â€ Ghose said. â€œIt will be an important message if this is done right at the top level. Once you allow this, it will percolate to the karyakarta [functionary] level.â€
